awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.  This Integrating Chemistry and Earth science (ICE) project will design, develop, and test a new curriculum unit for high school chemistry courses that is organized around the question, "How does chemistry shape where I live?"  The new unit will integrate relevant Earth science data, scientific practices, and key urban environmental research findings with the chemistry curriculum to gain insights into factors that support the approach to teaching and learning advocated by current science curriculum standards.  The overarching goal of the project is to develop teacher capacity to teach and evaluate student abilities to use the practices of scientists and concepts from Earth science and chemistry to understand important phenomena in their immediate, familiar environments.  The project has the potential to serve as a model for how to make cutting edge science directly accessible to all students.  The project is a collaborative effort that engages scientists, science education researchers, curriculum developers, school curriculum and instruction leaders, and science teachers in the longer term challenge of infusing Earth science concepts and practices across the core high school science courses.

Current guidelines and standards for science education promote learning that engages students in three interrelated dimensions: disciplinary core ideas, scientific practices, and crosscutting ideas.  This project is guided by the hypothesis that when provided sustained opportunities to engage in three-dimensional learning experiences, in an integrated Earth science and chemistry context, students will improve in their ability to demonstrate the coordination of disciplinary core ideas, scientific practices, and crosscutting concepts when solving problems and developing explanations related to scientific phenomena. This project will employ a design based research approach, and during the two development-enactment-analysis-and-redesign cycles, the project team will collect student assessment data, teacher interview data, observational data from lessons, teacher surveys, and reflective teacher logbooks. These collected data will provide information about how teachers implement the lessons, what students do during the lessons, and what students learn from them that will lead to better design and a better understanding of student learning. This information will be used to inform the modification of lessons from cycle to cycle, and to inform the professional development materials for teachers.  The research agenda for the project is guided by the following questions: 1. What are the design features of ICE lessons that support teachers in enacting three-dimensional instruction within the context of their classroom?  2. What are the design features of embedded three-dimensional assessments that yield useful classroom data for teachers and researchers regarding their students' abilities to integrate core ideas, scientific practices, and crosscutting concepts? 3. What is the nature of student learning related to disciplinary core ideas, scientific practices, and crosscutting concepts that results from students' engagement in ICE lesson sets? 4. What differences emerge in student engagement and learning outcomes for ICE lessons that incorporate local phenomena or data sets as compared to lessons that do not? 5. What contextual factors (i.e., school context, administrative support, time constraints, etc.) influence teachers' implementation of three-dimensional instruction embedded within ICE lessons?

por.por_cntn:
The Integrating Chemistry and Earth Science (ICE) project addressed the challenge of integrating Earth science and three dimensional (3D) teaching and learning into Baltimore City Public School’s high school chemistry curriculum. We hypothesized that instruction focusing on local environmental phenomena would help teachers engage students in learning that was synergistic across the two disciplines. We had three goals: 1) Develop, test and refine lessons and assessments for the seven unit chemistry curriculum that help teachers and students engage in 3D learning in an integrated Earth science and chemistry context. 2) Develop, test and provide professional development, in-school support and resources for district-wide adoption of the ICE curriculum. 3) Collect, analyze and present evidence to address research hypotheses about learning and teaching, and to provide feedback for curriculum and PL improvement and broader implementation.

For Goal 1 the team produced new versions of two of the seven chemistry units, blending disciplinary core ideas (DCIs) from Earth science and chemistry, science and engineering practices (SEPs, e.g., modeling), and cross cutting concepts (CCCs, e.g., matter and energy). The Thermochemistry unit features the Urban Heat Island phenomenon, and the Earth Chemistry unit explores how chemistry shapes the life and death of Baltimore’s mountains. Earth science DCIs and SEPs also were integrated into other units (e.g., ocean acidification in the chemical reactions unit).

For Goal 2, the project developed professional learning (PL) and support strategies to build chemistry teachers’ confidence in the new topics and 3D approaches. A small group of teachers engaged in intensive PL and in-class support, helping identify what was most needed for teachers to adopt the new material. From its inception, ICE materials were available to all District chemistry teachers, and at least one of the systemic PL sessions was devoted to ICE each year.

For Goal 3, data were collected from teachers and students, including assessments embedded directly in the curriculum and PL activities, end-of-unit assessments, interviews, observations and surveys.

Pursuing the complementary goals of developing and implementing an NGSS-aligned integrated curriculum (Goal 1) and understanding that process (Goal 3), project partners drew mutual benefit from the collaboration. District staff collaborated with ICE partners to enhance the chemistry curriculum to include phenomenon-based units that utilize a storyline, modeling, student inquiry, and discourse, and demonstrate a progression in learning as students create and revise a model of their knowledge and understanding. The ICE units served as a guide for all other high school science curricula being updated by school staff. Reflecting keen interest in our innovative approach to integrating Earth science with other sciences, the curriculum has been shared with a number of other Local Educational Agencies within the State. The curriculum is available on the City’s teacher portal, and two modules developed from it on the Cary Institute website.

Feedback from ICE teachers was instrumental in guiding work by District science staff in revising the PL framework for all science content sessions from K-12 (Goal 2). The PL models developed by ICE  are being used within the District’s systemic PL sessions for all chemistry teachers, helping  sustain the integrated approach to science instruction  envisioned at the outset of the project.

Research findings (Goal 3) demonstrate the intellectual merit of the ICE project and provide evidence of students’ abilities to engage in the sophisticated scientific practices of modeling, in order to explain locally relevant phenomena at the intersection of chemistry and Earth science, such as the urban heat island effect, which impacts the students’ local community. Over the span of the project, students demonstrated increased proficiency with integration of science content from the two disciplines to explain connections between important components of systems  to illustrate their understanding of these complex phenomena. At the same time, teacher participants grew in their understanding of the goals and requirements of 3D, phenomenon-based instruction. As active participants in ongoing PL, teachers were able to explore the affordances and associated constraints of this type of instruction. By supporting teachers’ pedagogical reasoning during PL, teachers were able to collaborate with their peers to solve problems of practice grounded within their own classrooms and schools. Over time, this collaborative work supported teachers’ development and deeper engagement with the curriculum creation, implementation, and revision process to move forward the district goal of NGSS alignment. Results were disseminated through publications, conference presentations, the STEM Video Showcase, workshops, and DRK12 PI meetings.

The strength of the research-practice partnership was an emergent outcome of ICE. This was evinced not just by success in meeting its goals, but also by its ability to pivot to provide on-line curriculum modules for at-home learning and virtual teacher workshops during the pandemic. The partnership is the foundation of the newly funded EarthX project that is bringing lessons from ICE to the District’s entire high school science curriculum sequence.
